newsitem.title: USA: Unocal closer to leaving Calif. refining.
newsitem.headline: Unocal closer to leaving Calif. refining.

text.p: Unocal Corp moved a step closer to leaving California's cutthroat refining and marketing business Tuesday by announcing it would give up ownership of downstream assets by year end.

Industry analysts said the move, the latest in a series of downstream divestments by Unocal, reflects intense competition in the West Coast market and as a desire by Unocal to focus its resources in more lucrative overseas markets.
"Unocal no longer has any production in California...They're no synergies between refining and marketing and oil and gas production," said Bruce Lanni, an analyst with Oppenheimer & Co.

76 Products Company, formed in 1994, will employ 3,100 people and hold about $2.7 billion in assets, including three refineries in California with a combined crude oil input capacity of 251,000 barrels per day. The unit will lease or own a chain of 1,200 service stations in six western states.
Among the options Unocal is considering for the downstream assets are an initial public offering, joint-venture, or sale.

"The timing for implementing one of these options depends upon 76 Products' continued progress in developing sustainable earnings and cash flow," Roger Beach, the company's chairman and chief executive officer, said in a statement.
Unocal's move follows the April sale of its California crude oil and natural gas assets to Nuevo Energy Co for $492 million.
The announcement came as no surprise to Wall Street, which has watched the competition for California's downstream business intensify recently.

Analysts in mid-October reported a sharp 21-percent decline in West Coast refining margins in the early weeks of the fourth quarter, reflecting rising crude oil prices and falling prices for gasoline.
"Industry-wide it hasn't been the rosiest business to be in," said Philip Tendler, an analyst for Schroder Wertheim & Co.

By comparison, the percentage of Unocal's overseas crude oil production is expected to grow in the next year to around 60 percent of its total 220,000 barrel-per-day output from about 48 percent this year.
But while 76 Company will only say many changes are on the horizon, analysts see no refinery closures as a result of the spin-off.
"It's impact on the overall California market should be negligible," Tendler said.
